thread.title: Invercargill's first Melbourne Cup flight nearly full
thread.title_full: Invercargill's first Melbourne Cup flight nearly full

author: Briar Babington
title: Invercargill's first Melbourne Cup flight nearly full
text:
Invercargill's first Melbourne Cup flight nearly full BRIAR BABINGTON Last updated 13:29, October 13 2015 NICOLE JOHNSTONE/FAIRFAX NZ 
House of Travel Lakers owner-operator Tony Laker has almost sold all the seats on his Melbourne Cup flight. 
With the big day less than one month away and the itinerary finalised, Invercargill travel agent Tony Laker can barely contain his excitement. 
It's full steam ahead for Invercargill's first international flight, which will be winging its way across the ditch for the Melbourne Cup on November 3. 
READ MORE: Invercargill's first international flight 
Laker is putting the final touches on what he says will be "a hell of a good day out". 
After snapping up an A320 airbus from a cancelled Christchurch to Melbourne flight, Laker said he wanted to create a special event for the region. 
There are just 15 seats left on the flight, and Laker is hoping the final spots will be picked up before ticket sales close at 5pm on Friday. 
Regardless, the trip will go ahead and will be finalised with Air New Zealand on Monday, he said. 
"We've got a lot of excited people ready to go," Laker said. 
"There's going to be lots of laughs and lots of excitement, no question about that." 
Cup-goers are in for a big day - they will be checking in at the Invercargill airport at 5am on November 3 and returning at 1.30am the next day. Ad Feedback 
The flight will be full of southerners, with travellers from as far as Central Otago making their way to Invercargill for the special charter flight. 
Racing enthusiasts and fashionistas would be on the flight, along with a few people wanting to tick an item off their bucket list. 
Laker said it had been a massive organisational process, having to confirm the details of the trip with Mission Aviation Fellowship (MAF), New Zealand Customs, Aviation Security, Air New Zealand, and Invercargill and Melbourne airports. 
There had been considerable interest travellers and the media, Laker said. 
"No-one else is doing that around the country. It really shows what Southland can do." - Stuff
